Well, I do think the region makes a big difference.

Finances is a stressor to marriage.

The statistics even show that when there is a significant or dramatic increase in income, that that is an added financial stressor that leads to an increase in divorce.

But if you have a level of economic distress that is so severe that they can no longer afford to leave, especially when you have an economic problem that is around the housing market, where that is usually your biggest asset, sometimes the minor irritations, trials and tribulations of being a married couple might seem more tolerable if you can't get rid of your house.

They know what they are angry about, but do not understand the source of the problem.

Love does not conquer all, and there are - everyone has a different feeling about money, about control, about power, about the dishes.
And those conversations, if they're not being had before marriage, they spark up as problems and end up being something other than what they started out to be.
